awd_titl_txt: U.S. Annual Dues Support for the International Arctic Science Committee (IASC) and the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR) - 2011 - 2013
awd_abstract_narration: The Polar Research Board (PRB) within the National Academies serves as the US Committee to the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR) and the International Arctic Science Committee (IASC). This award covers the dues for the US participation in the SCAR and the IASC. US participation in SCAR and IASC gives the US a voice in international research and policies concerning the polar regions.

por.por_cntn:
The Polar Research Board (PRB) of the U.S. National Academy of Sciences has a mission to advance understanding of the polar regions; foster application of polar science to benefit the public and decision makers; advise U.S. research programs so they are responsive to the needs of the nation; encourage interdisciplinary and cross polar perspectives; and provide a forum for independent discussion of polar issues. The PRB also serves as the U.S. National Committee (USNC) to two international nongovernmental polar science organizations -- the International Arctic Science Committee (IASC), and the Scientific Committee on Antarctic Research (SCAR).   U.S. annual dues support for these organizations is crucially important for advancing opportunities and interests of the U.S. polar research community, and for assuring continued progress in international-level research and assessment activities.

IASC is a non-governmental organization that encourages and facilitates cooperation in all aspects of arctic research, in all countries engaged in arctic research and in all areas of the arctic region. To fulfill its mission, IASC promotes and supports leading-edge multi-disciplinary research in order to foster a greater scientific understanding of the arctic region and its role in the Earth system. IASC has 22 member countries; members are usually national science organizations covering all fields of arctic research.

SCAR is a committee of the International Council for Science (ICSU), and it is charged with the initiation, promotion and co-ordination of scientific research in Antarctica. SCAR also provides international, independent scientific advice to the Antarctic Treaty system and other bodies. Full Members are those countries with active scientific research program in Antarctica (currently 31); Union Members are those ICSU scientific unions that have an interest in Antarctic research, (currently 9); and Associate Members are those countries without an independent research program as yet or which are planning a research program in the future (currently 6).

The PRB has continued its usual responsibilities as U.S. National Committee to SCAR and IASC, such as facilitating communication and coordination of SCAR and IASC activities in the United States, providing a forum at the PRB meetings to discuss issues of importance to SCAR and IASC, and sharing comments and input on various SCAR and IASC initiatives. The PRB communicates regularly with the Delegates and members of the polar research community on issues of importance in international polar science. PRB also supports SCAR and IASC outreach efforts through emails, newsletter communications, and conference calls.

The PRB's role as US National Committee to SCAR and IASC means that we facilitate the participation and leadership of U.S. scientists in international research and assessment activities, which help to build good will, establish relationships, and ensure U.S. visibility in the international scientific community. SCAR and IASC often provide critical input to international policy decisions through the Antarctic Treaty process and through the Arctic Council. Thus our efforts to support these programs can often affect important policy and management decisions.

The PRB selects the U.S. Delegates and the members of the U.S. delegation, through which the PRB facilitates U.S. participation in the biennial SCAR meetings and the annual IASC meetings. The U.S. delegates to IASC and SCAR also serve as ex-officio members of the PRB to ensure communication and coordination.

Dr. Terry Wilson (Ohio State University) serves as the U.S. Delegate to SCAR. Dr. Wilson also serves as the chief officer for the new Scientific Research Programme Solid Earth Response and Influence on Cryosphere Evolution (SERCE).
